bcl:section.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Environmental Management Act;
advanced treatment means any form of treatment, other than dilution, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: produces a municipal effluent quality with BOD5 and TSS being 10 mg/L or less each, and
meets applicable substituted requirements identified by a director under section 8 [director may substitute requirements];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: ADWF means the average dry weather flow,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: being the daily municipal wastewater flow to a wastewater facility that occurs after an extended period of dry weather such that the inflow and infiltration has been minimized to the greatest extent practicable, and
calculated in accordance with section 2 [calculation of ADWF and dilution ratio];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: assurance plan means a program described in section 31 [assurance plan];
BOD5 means the carbonaceous 5-day biochemical oxygen demand;
capital replacement fund means a fund described in section 29 (b) [security];

combined sewer system means ditches, drains, sewers, treatment facilities and disposal facilities that collect, transport, treat or discharge a combination of municipal wastewater and stormwater in a single system;
continuous monitoring system means a communications system that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enables operating conditions of a wastewater facility to be continuously monitored,
provides an alarm if operating conditions deviate from established operating conditions, and
enables operating conditions to be adjusted, remotely or by service call, to within normal efficient operating range within 24 hours of any alarm;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: contributory population means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number of persons connected to the municipal wastewater collection system, and
the equivalent commercial and industrial contributions of municipal wastewater to that municipal wastewater collection system;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: dilution ratio means the dilution ratio calculated in accordance with section 2 [calculation of ADWF and dilution ratio];
discharge means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: when used as a noun, the total amount of municipal wastewater, including reclaimed water, released into the receiving environment from works, and
when used as a verb, to release a discharge;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: discharger means a person authorized under this regulation to discharge;
disinfection means the destruction, inactivation or removal by any means of pathogenic microorganisms;
domestic wastewater has the same meaning as "domestic sewage" in the Sewerage System Regulation, B.C. Reg. 326/2004;
embayed marine waters means marine waters

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: located within a bay from which the access to the sea, by any route, has a maximum width of less than 1.5 km,
located, if a line less than 6 km long is drawn between any 2 points on a continuous coastline, on the shore side of the line, or
in which flushing action is identified in a notice given by a director to be inadequate;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: environmental impact study means an environmental impact study conducted in accordance with Division 3 [Environmental Impact Studies] of Part 2;
EOCP means Environmental Operators Certification Program;
filtration means the removal of solid particles from municipal effluent by passing the municipal effluent through

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a filtering medium such as sand, membrane or anthracite, or any other comparable filtering medium or combination of filtering media, or
a physical barrier, device or septum onto which the solids are deposited;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: groundwater means subsurface water at or below a water table in fully saturated geologic materials and formations;
health officer has the same meaning as in the Public Health Act;
inflow and infiltration means water that enters a municipal wastewater collection system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: directly from a stormwater connection (inflow),
indirectly through the land (infiltration), or
through both (a) and (b);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: irrigation means the application of reclaimed water at agronomic rates when irrigating vegetation;
land means the solid part of the earth's surface, and includes the foreshore and land covered by water;
MPN means most probable number;
municipal effluent means the liquid resulting from the treatment of municipal wastewater;
municipal wastewater means domestic wastewater or municipal liquid waste, including contributions from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holding tanks in recreational vehicles, boats and houseboats,
commercial, institutional and industrial sources,
inflow and infiltration,
septic tank pumpage,
holding tank solids, and
sludge from wastewater facilities;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: municipal wastewater collection system means a conveyance system operated and maintained for the purpose of transporting municipal wastewater to a wastewater treatment facility, but does not include wastewater treatment and discharge facilities;
NTU means nephelometric turbidity unit;
open marine waters means marine waters other than embayed marine waters;
primary treatment means any form of treatment, other than dilution, that produces a municipal effluent quality with BOD5 and TSS being not more than 130 mg/L each;

qualified professional means an applied scientist or technologist specializing in a particular applied science or technology, including agrology, biology, chemistry, engineering, geology or hydrogeology,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who is registered in British Columbia with the professional organization responsible for the applied scientist's or techonologist's area of expertise, acting under that professional association's code of ethics and subject to disciplinary action by that association, and

who, through suitable education, experience, accreditation and knowledge, may be reasonably relied on to provide advice within the applied scientist's or techonologist's area of expertise as it relates to this regulation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: reclaimed water means municipal wastewater that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: treated by a wastewater facility, and
suitable for reuse in accordance with this regulation;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: residential development means a dwelling or collection of dwellings that serve as the primary residence of the majority of their inhabitants, all of whom rely on a discharger to provide a municipal wastewater system;
secondary treatment means any form of treatment, other than dilution, that produces a municipal effluent quality with,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a lagoon system, BOD5 being not more than 45 mg/L and TSS being not more than 60 mg/L, and
in any other case, BOD5 and TSS being not more than 45 mg/L each;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: security means security calculated in accordance with section 29 [security];
septic tank means a watertight vessel into which municipal wastewater is continually conveyed such that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: solids within the municipal wastewater settle,
anaerobic digestion of organic materials occurs, and
municipal effluent is discharged;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: stormwater means runoff from rainfall, snow or snowmelt;
TSS means the total suspended solids or non-filterable residue;
wastewater facility means any facility or works that gathers, treats, transports, stores, uses or discharges municipal wastewater or reclaimed water;
water quality guidelines means, as published under the authority of the minister,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the water quality guidelines that, by approval of the minister, apply in British Columbia to groundwater and surface water,
in relation to a body of water for which water quality objectives have been established, the most recent water quality objectives, or
if neither of paragraphs (a) or (b) applies, any other water quality standard acceptable to the minister;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: water table means the surface

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: along which the fluid pressure is atmospheric, and
below which the fluid pressure is greater than atmospheric;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: water well means a well used to supply water for domestic purposes and, for the purposes of this definition,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: domestic purposes has the same meaning as in the Drinking Water Protection Act, and
well has the same meaning as in the Water Sustainability Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Calculation of ADWF and dilution ratio

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The ADWF is calculated by dividing the total flow to the wastewater facility during the dry weather period by the number of days in that period.
The dilution ratio is calculated

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by dividing the 2-year return period 7-day low flow in the receiving stream by the maximum weekly (7-day) municipal effluent flow, or

if sufficient data are not available to calculate the 2-year return period 7-day low flow or if the discharge is to a lake or marine waters, a ratio calculated using a method and data as authorized by a director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal effluent quality requirements not to be exceeded
bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless stated otherwise, the municipal effluent quality requirements set out in Parts 5 to 7 are maximum values and must not be exceeded.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, parcel, sewerage system and strata lot have the same meanings as in the Sewerage System Regulation, B.C. Reg. 326/2004.
Subject to subsection (3), this regulation applies to all discharges

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to ground, if the discharge

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is equal to or exceeds maximum daily flows of 22.7 m3/d, and
is from a sewerage system or combination of sewerage systems that serve structures on one or more parcels or strata lots, or on a shared interest, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This regulation does not apply to a discharge to ground or water if the discharge is from a sewerage system that serves only a single family residence or duplex.
This regulation applies to all uses of reclaimed water unless the reclaimed water is from a sewerage system that serves only a single family residence or duplex.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Persons who may discharge or provide reclaimed water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is exempt from section 6 (2) and (3) of the Act and may discharge municipal effluent or provide reclaimed water if the person does so

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in accordance with this regulation, or
to a wastewater facility that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is authorized under the Act to discharge to the receiving environment, and
accepts and processes municipal wastewater as 10% or less of its waste stream.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is exempt from section 6 (2) and (3) of the Act and may discharge domestic wastewater to a sewerage system within the meaning of the Sewerage System Regulation, B.C. Reg. 326/2004, if the person is subject to, and complies with, that regulation.
This section applies despite any provision of this regulation.

Subject to subsection (3), a person must not discharge municipal effluent, or register under Part 2 of this regulation for the purposes of discharging municipal effluent, in a manner that would conflict with a liquid waste management plan that is approved by the minister.
Subsection (2) does not apply to a discharger registered before November 17, 2005 with a director in relation to a discharge to Shuswap Lake.
In this section, non-domestic waste means liquid waste other than domestic wastewater.

A person must not discharge non-domestic waste to a municipal wastewater facility unless the person ensures that the pre-discharge quality of the non-domestic waste meets the standards or is within the ranges specified in the Standard for Discharges Directed to Municipal or Industrial Effluent Treatment Works under Column 3 of Schedule 1.2 of the Hazardous Waste Regulation, B.C. Reg. 63/88.
A municipality must not accept non-domestic waste to a municipal wastewater collection system unless the municipality

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: regulates the introduction of non-domestic waste through a source control bylaw, or equivalent measures, that provides for the pre-treatment of industrial, commercial and institutional discharges to the system, or
demonstrates, by way of a study, that a source control bylaw, or equivalent measures, is not required to protect

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the wastewater facility that receives and processes the municipal wastewater, or
the receiving environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may, on receipt of an application or on the director's own initiative, substitute a different requirement for a requirement contained in this regulation if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the substitution is necessary to protect the public or the receiving environment, or
the intent of this regulation will be met by the substitution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (1), if water quality objectives have not been established, the director may require a discharger to establish a background water quality limit for the receiving environment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a director

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: makes a substitution under section 8 [director may substitute requirements],
gives notice of, authorizes or accepts a matter under this regulation, or
waives a requirement under section 39 (2) [septic tanks], 54 [monitoring facilities and devices], 58 [toxicity monitoring requirements] or 114 (2) or (3) [alternate disposal or storage],

bcl:section.bcl:text: the substitution, notice, authorization, acceptance or waiver must be made in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who registers in accordance with this Division is authorized to do either of the following in accordance with this regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: discharge municipal effluent to ground or water;
discharge or use reclaimed water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Registration takes effect on the date a director notifies the person that all of the following have been received in the form and manner acceptable to the director:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information and records required under sections 11 [administrative information] to 15 [certification by qualified professionals];
any other relevant information or record requested by the director;
payment in accordance with section 2 of the Permit and Approval Fees and Charges Regulation, B.C. Reg. 299/92;
if required under Division 5 [Security and Assurance Plans],

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: proof that the person has established security and a capital replacement fund, or
an assurance plan acceptable to a director

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in compliance with the requirements of that Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notification under subsection (2) is not evidence that the requirements of the Act or this regulation have been met.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following administrative information is required for registration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the full legal name and address of the person to be registered;
the name of a local contact for the person to be registered, and the contact's local address;
the name of the operator of the wastewater facility;
in respect of the land on which the wastewater facility is to be located,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the address and legal description, or the name, latitude and longitude, and
the name of the registered owner;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the address and legal description, or the name, latitude and longitude, of the location of the discharge;
if the person to be registered has a previous waste management permit respecting discharges to the environment that will be the subject of registration under this regulation, the permit number.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following technical information is required for registration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the wastewater facility;
in respect of the discharge from the wastewater facility, a statement of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the maximum daily flow of the discharge,
the applicable municipal effluent quality requirements, and
the municipal effluent and receiving environment monitoring program, including frequency, notification and reporting requirements;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for reclaimed water uses, a statement of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the applicable category as described in section 104 [categories of reclaimed water], and
the rationale for selecting that category.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information respecting wastewater facility design, plans and studies
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following information respecting wastewater facility design, plans and studies is required for registration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of all environmental impact studies;
a copy of design drawings for the wastewater facility, including the discharge works, signed and stamped by a qualified professional;
an operating plan made in accordance with Division 4 [Operating Plans];
a site plan showing the receiving environment monitoring sites in relation to the location of the wastewater facility and the discharge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Proof of the following is required for registration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if water conservation measures are significant to the design of the wastewater facility, that restrictive covenants respecting the measures are in place;
if approval to construct the wastewater facility is required by the relevant municipality, that the person has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: applied for a development permit, and
notified the relevant municipality of the intent to register under this regulation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the approval of a health officer is required for the use of reclaimed water under this regulation, that a health officer has been notified of, or has approved, the use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a local service area bylaw applies to the construction or operation of a wastewater facility, a copy of the bylaw must be included with the registration.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Statements, signed and sealed by the appropriate qualified professionals, certifying all of the following must be provided on registration:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the design of the proposed wastewater facility and the associated documentation meet the requirements of this regulation;
the proposed discharge from the wastewater facility will meet the requirements of this regulation;
all required environmental impact studies have been conducted in accordance with this regulation;
the operating plan for the proposed wastewater facility is adequate for its design;
if an assurance plan is provided, the assurance plan is adequate to provide for repairs to, or the operation, maintenance or replacement of, the wastewater facility;

if a director imposes conditions, limitations or requirements in respect of a substitution, notice, authorization, acceptance or waiver referred to in section 9 [director must act in writing], those conditions, limitations or requirements have been addressed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there is a change in the information referred to in subsection (2), a discharger is not required to re-register, but the discharger must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify a director within 30 days of the change, and
provide the director with the revised information.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The information for the purposes of subsection (1) is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a change in the information submitted for registration under section 11 (a), (b), (c) or (d) (ii) [administrative information];
a change in the quantity of the discharge if the resulting quantity, measured in relation to the quantity initially registered, is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: decreased, or
increased by not more than 10%;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a change in the quality of the discharge if the resulting quality, measured in relation to the quality initially registered, has no greater impact on public health or the receiving environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registration may be transferred as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 30 days before the transfer, the discharger must notify a director of the intended transfer;

after notification under paragraph (a) but at least 30 days before the transfer, the person to whom the registration is being transferred must provide the director with all applicable changes to the information required under this Division in respect of the registration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may suspend or cancel a registration in the same manner and for the same reasons as a director could suspend or cancel a permit or approval under section 18 of the Act.
A discharger must not release a discharge

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: during any period during which the discharger's registration is suspended, or
if the discharger's registration is cancelled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a person must conduct an environmental impact study as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of registration under Division 2 [Registration];
if registered under Division 2, before expanding or making a material change to the person's wastewater facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person was authorized, before July 15, 1999, to discharge or use reclaimed water, subsection (1) (b) does not apply unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a director notifies the person otherwise, or
the person is making a material change in respect of treatment, effluent quality or amount of discharge, if the amount is to be increased, from that which was authorized.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must conduct for a wastewater facility an environmental impact study that includes provisions for controlling environmental impacts during the construction and operation of the wastewater facility or site.
A qualified professional must conduct for the receiving environment an environmental impact study that does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: considers the potential cumulative effects of the discharge on the receiving environment;
establishes additional municipal effluent quality requirements if necessary to protect public health or the receiving environment;
for the purposes of section 20 [receiving environment monitoring program], establishes in relation to both pre- and post-discharge

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: receiving environment monitoring locations, and
sampling parameters and frequencies;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: demonstrates, with regard to the nature of the discharge and the receiving environment, that the proposed disposal system, treatment and reuse, and the discharges from these, will not adversely affect public health or the receiving environment;
addresses any impact on the receiving environment when

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: municipal effluent quality or reclaimed water requirements are met, and
municipal effluent or reclaimed water is degraded.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must establish a receiving environment monitoring program that does all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provides for at least one control sampling station located upstream, upgradient or outside the influence of the initial dilution zone of the municipal effluent;
obtains data to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: assess the potential impact of the discharge or reclaimed water, and
ensure that the discharge or reclaimed water does not or will not cause water quality parameters, outside the initial dilution zone, to fail to meet water quality guidelines;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: documents pre-discharge conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If seasonal variations are significant in the receiving environment, a discharger must conduct pre-discharge monitoring during the most critical period of the year.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If section 42 [overflows] applies to a discharge, a qualified professional must conduct an environmental impact study that identifies

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any measures necessary to protect public health and the receiving environment, and
any treatment needed to protect the designated uses of waters receiving combined sewer system overflows or municipal wastewater collection system overflows.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division does not apply to a municipal wastewater collection system.
A qualified professional must prepare for a wastewater facility an operating plan that details the requirements for all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proper operation, maintenance and monitoring of the wastewater facility, including lift stations;
staff education and certification;
a commissioning plan, a contingency plan and, if applicable, an irrigation plan, each made by the qualified professional in accordance with this Division;
in the case of a temporary treatment system, a closure plan, made by the qualified professional, that describes the procedures for decommissioning the system when it is no longer required.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A commissioning plan must include the operational procedures required to commission the wastewater facility, including the monitoring required to demonstrate that no adverse environmental impacts result from commissioning.
A contingency plan must describe all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: emergency procedures for the wastewater facility, including lift stations;
procedures for notifying a health officer when necessary;
actions to be taken if municipal effluent quality fails to meet the requirements of this regulation;
an alternate method of disposal or storage if reclaimed water use is not possible.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An irrigation plan must describe all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appropriate use, including the time of use, of reclaimed water;
the maximum application rate, and the growing season, for the crop or vegetation to which the reclaimed water is applied;
the site-specific loading, vegetation nutrient and metal limits.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Division does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a municipality, or
a person who discharges from a service area defined and governed by a local service area bylaw.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a discharger who is an individual, company or strata corporation must not treat, reuse or discharge municipal wastewater generated by a residential development unless all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: security is maintained with a financial institution in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an amount calculated in accordance with section 29 (a) [security], and
a form acceptable to a director;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharger provides to a director, within 90 days of the end of the discharger's fiscal year, audited annual financial statements of the discharger's capital replacement fund;
the discharger ensures that a director can act in a timely manner as set out in section 30 [use of security and capital replacement fund] respecting the security and capital replacement fund.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a discharger who is covered by an assurance plan acceptable to a director under this Division.
Subsection (1) (b) does not apply to a discharger who has been registered under Division 2 [Registration] for less than one year.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of submitting proof under section 10 (2) (d) (i) [registration] that a person has established security and a capital replacement fund, a person must establish both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: security in an amount calculated by multiplying the maximum daily flow in m3/d by $1 400, rounded up to the nearest $1 000, and
a capital replacement fund composed of cash, securities, bonds or other financial instruments or insurance, or a combination of these, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: ensures that the potential cost, whenever it may arise, of full replacement of a wastewater facility will be covered,

is adjusted annually to match inflation based on the Industrial Product Price Index in respect of capital equipment, produced by Statistics Canada, with the year the wastewater facility was registered as the base year, and
is not assignable or refundable.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of security and capital replacement fund

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the security or contributions, or both, from the capital replacement fund established under section 29 [security] may, at the discretion of a director, be accessed and used for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the repair, operation, maintenance, replacement or improvement of a wastewater facility, or
the payment of any insurance policy premiums or deductibles.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) applies only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the director notifies the discharger that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: one or more of the actions listed in subsection (1) (a) or (b) must be taken within a reasonable time specified by the director, and
if the action or actions are not taken, the security or contributions, or both, are required, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the actions are not taken within the time specified by the director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must replenish a capital replacement fund from which contributions are made unless a director authorizes alternative arrangements to ensure that the potential cost, whenever it may arise, of full replacement of the wastewater facility will be covered.
For the purposes of having an assurance plan that is acceptable to a director under section 10 (2) (d) (ii) [registration], a person must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: register the wastewater facility with a program

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for which insurance instruments are provided by a company registered under the Insurance Act with the Superintendent of Insurance, and

that has sufficient quality assurance and technical, financial and management resources to provide, or secure the provision of, repairs to, or for the operation, maintenance or replacement of, each wastewater facility registered with the program;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the person's expense, ensure that an expert consultant selected from the roster established under subsection (2) has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: reviewed the assurance plan, and
made a recommendation to the director on the acceptability of the assurance plan;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attach to the assurance plan the findings of the consultant who reviewed the plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may establish a roster of expert consultants to assist in reviewing assurance plans.
A person must not select a consultant who has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: been involved in developing the assurance plan being reviewed, or
a personal or business relationship with the person requiring the review.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may accept an assurance plan if satisfied that it adequately provides for the matters described in subsection (1) (a) (ii).

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not design a wastewater facility, including a pumping facility, outfall or other works associated with a wastewater facility, for the purposes of this regulation unless the person is a qualified professional.

In designing a wastewater facility, a qualified professional must ensure that the wastewater facility will at all times achieve the applicable municipal effluent quality requirements under this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: long term effluent degradation means a degradation in the quality of municipal effluent for a period continuing over several days;
shellfish waters means bodies of water capable of supporting shellfish in quantities that permit aboriginal, commercial or recreational shellfish harvesting;
short term effluent degradation means a degradation in the quality of municipal effluent for a period of even a few hours.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this regulation, reliability categories are defined as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: category I, being wastewater facilities

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that discharge to ground or water, and

in respect of which short term effluent degradation could cause permanent or unacceptable damage to the receiving environment, including discharges near drinking water sources, shellfish waters or recreational waters in which direct human contact occurs;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: category II, being wastewater facilities

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that discharge to ground or water, and

in respect of which permanent or unacceptable damage to the receiving environment, including discharges to recreational waters and land, would not be caused by short term effluent degradation but would be caused by long term effluent degradation;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: category III, being wastewater facilities that do not fall within reliability category I or II.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determine, based on an environmental impact study, which reliability category applies to a proposed wastewater facility, and
ensure that the design of the wastewater facility meets the applicable requirements of Table 1 and section 36 [additional component and reliability requirements].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of Table 1, the remaining capacity with the largest unit out of service must be at least

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 50% of the design maximum flow where the notation "a" appears, or
75% of the design maximum flow where the notation "b" appears.

2 units or ability to repair within 48 hours

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of diffuser requirements, a qualified professional must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: diffusers must have multiple sections, and
the maximum oxygen transfer capability must not be measurably impaired with the largest section out of service.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of blowers or mechanical aerators, a qualified professional must ensure that the remaining capacity with the largest unit out of service is able to achieve design maximum oxygen transfer.
In respect of holding basin requirements for a wastewater facility within reliability category I, a qualified professional must ensure that the treatment system has adequate capacity for all flows.

In respect of chemical flash mixer requirements for a wastewater facility within reliability category I and having only one basin, a qualified professional must provide for a backup system with at least 2 mixing devices, one of which may be installed.

In respect of package treatment plants for a wastewater facility within reliability category I, a qualified professional must provide for municipal effluent filtration in conjunction with discharging to ground.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In designing pumping facilities, a qualified professional must ensure that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are at least 2 pumps, with each pump capable of pumping peak design flows;
for pumping stations requiring multiple pumps, the station must have sufficient capacity to pump peak design flow when the largest pump is out of service;
for a 2-pump station, a receptacle for a portable generator must be available for standby power;
for a multiple pump station, an on-site generator must be available for standby power;
standby power must be capable of being activated before the hydraulic capacity of the pump station is exceeded.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must not design the construction or expansion of a combined sewer system.
Nothing in subsection (1) prevents a person from making emergency repairs to an existing combined sewer system.
If repairs are made to a combined sewer system, a discharger must ensure that the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assesses the feasibility of sewer separation, and
separates, if possible, the storm and municipal wastewater collection systems at the time of repair.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In designing a wastewater facility using a septic tank, a qualified professional must ensure that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tank has a hydraulic capacity of at least 2 days' minimum detention time at the design maximum daily flow;
the tank is fitted with an effluent filter, a screen or an equivalent measure to protect pumps and prevent discharge of solids and floatables;
the tank is accessible for pump out.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may waive the requirement set out in subsection (1) (b) in respect of small, remote, seasonal discharges to water.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not begin construction of a wastewater facility until the earlier of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: being notified under section 10 (2) [registration] that registration is effective, and
receiving notice from a director that construction may begin.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Overflows, and Inflow and Infiltration Requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: combined sewer overflow means a discharge from a combined sewer system to a location other than a wastewater facility;

municipal wastewater collection system overflow means a discharge from a municipal wastewater collection system to a location other than a wastewater facility, commonly referred to as a sanitary sewer overflow.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may, on written request from a discharger, extend any date in this Division.
A discharger must ensure that an overflow does not occur during storm or snowmelt events with a less than 5-year return period, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for municipal wastewater collection systems for which the contributory population is 10 000 persons or more, the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system develops and implements, as part of a liquid waste management plan, measures to eliminate overflows, or
if paragraph (a) does not apply, the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system or combined sewer system

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: develops a liquid waste management plan or conducts a study, and
develops and implements measures to eventually eliminate overflows.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), on the request of a director, a discharger must ensure that the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system or combined sewer system prepares a record at least once in each 10-year period containing all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an estimate of the volume, frequency and number of overflow occurrences for each overflow location;
an assessment of the potential impact of overflow occurrences on the receiving environment at each overflow location;
a record of each overflow occurrence that occurs during storm or snowmelt events with a less than 5-year return period;
based on the estimate in paragraph (a), an estimate of the total annual volume of all overflow occurrences that occur during storm or snowmelt events with a less than 5-year return period;
a plan for reducing the volume estimated under paragraph (d) by an average of,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of combined sewer overflows, 1% per year over a 10-year period, or
in the case of municipal wastewater collection system overflows, 10% per year over a 10-year period;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the steps that have been or will be taken to reduce the volume, frequency and number of overflow occurrences.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of storage or conveyance facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger may not use storage or conveyance facilities to reduce

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of sewer separation required, or
the amount of inflow and infiltration reduction required

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless the facilities immediately reduce and ultimately prevent the occurrence of combined sewer overflows.
If facilities are used under subsection (1) and primary and secondary treatment is available, the discharger must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide at least primary treatment for flows greater than 2 times the ADWF;
use the full secondary capacity of the treatment system;
combine the primary and secondary municipal effluent prior to discharge;
maintain a minimum receiving environment-to-discharge dilution ratio of 40:1;
if disinfection is required, provide adequate excess disinfection capacity to ensure disinfection of the entire discharge flow.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that inflow and infiltration does not occur such that the maximum average daily flow exceeds 2 times the ADWF at the treatment plant during storm or snowmelt events with a less than 5-year return period, unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for municipal wastewater collection systems for which the contributory population to the treatment plant is 10 000 persons or more, the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system addresses, as part of a liquid waste management plan, how inflow and infiltration can be reduced, or
if paragraph (a) does not apply, the person responsible for the municipal wastewater collection system

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: develops a liquid waste management plan or conducts a study, and
develops and implements measures to reduce inflow and infiltration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), if reductions below 2 times the ADWF are not possible or cost effective based on a cost-benefit analysis, the discharger must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide full secondary treatment for the entire flow at all times, or
undertake to do all of the things listed in section 43 (2) (a) to (e) [use of storage or conveyance facilities].

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must not discharge until ensuring that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the design of the wastewater facility meets, and is capable of consistently meeting,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the requirements of this regulation, or
the requirements, if any, substituted under section 8 [director may substitute requirements];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a qualified professional having expertise in the particular aspect of the design has undertaken

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the flow calculation,
the wastewater facility design, and
an inspection to ensure that the construction methods and materials, and the wastewater facility as constructed, meet the design criteria;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the wastewater facility is classified under the EOCP.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 to 60 days before beginning to discharge, provide to a director

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: notice that discharge will begin, and
a copy of final design drawings reflecting the actual construction of the wastewater facility, certified as correct and sealed by a qualified professional;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not more than 7 days after beginning to discharge, provide to a director notice of the date that discharge began.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must not discharge unless the wastewater facility is operated and maintained by persons who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have the education, experience and qualifications specified in the operating plan, and
are certified under the EOCP.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must adhere to the operating plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not bypass a wastewater facility, or any component of the wastewater facility, for the purpose of scheduled maintenance unless maintenance cannot reasonably be undertaken without the bypass.
If a bypass under subsection (1) may cause a discharge to fail to meet a requirement set out in this regulation, the discharger must do all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify a director at least 30 days before beginning the bypass;
receive authorization from a director before beginning the bypass;
comply with any conditions imposed by the director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All unauthorized bypasses, overflows and spills must be reported in accordance with the Spill Reporting Regulation, B.C. Reg. 263/90.
If a malfunction or other condition results, or may result, in a discharge that fails to meet a requirement of this regulation, a discharger must notify a director immediately.
A discharger must notify a health officer immediately of any malfunction or other condition related to the wastewater facility that may result in a risk to public health.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The discharger must not discharge municipal effluent unless, at the edge of the initial dilution zone, all water quality guidelines are met.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must disinfect municipal effluent if necessary to ensure that receiving water or groundwater used for domestic or agricultural water extraction, recreational uses or aquatic food production meets water quality guidelines.
A discharger must not use chlorination to disinfect municipal effluent without authorization from a director unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharger first considers alternative disinfection methods, and
the municipal effluent discharged to surface water is dechlorinated below 0.02 mg/L total residual chlorine before discharge.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not discharge, or provide or use reclaimed water, unless the discharger monitors

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharge or reclaimed water, and
the receiving environment

bcl:section.bcl:text: to determine compliance with this regulation.
A discharger must do both of the following, unless one or both requirements are waived by a director:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: install, or provide, a suitable sampling facility for obtaining a sample of the municipal effluent or reclaimed water;
provide and maintain a suitable flow measuring device to record, for each 24-hour period,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the municipal effluent volume discharged, and
the volume of reclaimed water treated and used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must monitor the quality and quantity of municipal effluent or reclaimed water, as applicable, in accordance with Parts 5 [Specific Requirements for Discharge to Ground] to 7 [Reclaimed Water Requirements] for at least the first 2 years of discharge.
In respect of seasonal or intermittent discharges, a director may authorize an alternate monitoring schedule.
For new discharges, a person must begin monitoring on beginning to discharge or provide reclaimed water.
After 2 years of discharging or providing reclaimed water, a director may authorize alternate monitoring requirements based on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the monitoring data,
written recommendations of a qualified professional, or
any other information related to the discharge or the receiving environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must submit municipal effluent flow, municipal effluent quality and receiving environment monitoring data, and associated quality control data,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by electronic transmission directly to the central computer system of the ministry of the minister, or
in a form acceptable to a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must adhere to the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if required to sample quarterly, there must be at least 2 months between samples;
if required to sample monthly, there must be at least 10 days between samples;
if required to sample twice a month, there must be at least 7 days between samples;
if required to sample weekly, there must be at least 5 days between samples;
weekly composite samples must include samples from 3 days each week, with at least one day between samples;
if required to sample twice a week, there must be at least 2 days between samples;
daily composite samples must be composited in proportion to flow over 24 hours.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of sections 86 [monitoring requirements for discharges to ground] and 103 [monitoring requirements for discharges to water], chemical oxygen demand may be used in place of BOD5 if BOD5 is examined with chemical oxygen demand every fifth sampling.
In subsections (2) and (3) (a):

bcl:definition.bcl:text: ministry means the ministry of the minister;
standard practice means those standards and procedures that are necessary to ensure that measurements and analyses produce valid and reliable results.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that sampling and flow measurements are carried out in accordance with standard practice and, for this purpose, may have regard to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the standards and procedures as set out in the sampling and laboratory manuals posted to the ministry website, or

if the standards and procedures described in paragraph (a) do not apply, the standards and procedures as described in British Columbia Field Sampling Manual: 2003 – For Continuous Monitoring and the Collection of Air, Air-Emission, Water, Wastewater, Soil, Sediment and Biological Samples, as published by the ministry and as amended from time to time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that analysis is carried out in accordance with standard practice and, for this purpose, may have regard to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the standards and procedures as described in British Columbia Environmental Laboratory Manual: 2009, as published by the ministry and as amended from time to time, or
suitable alternative procedures as authorized by the Resources Information Standards Committee of the ministry of the minister responsible for the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must submit laboratory analyses required by this regulation in accordance with the Environmental Data Quality Assurance Regulation, B.C. Reg. 301/90.

In addition to the requirements under section 103 [monitoring requirements for discharges to water], a person must not discharge to water, other than open marine waters, unless the discharge is monitored for toxicity in accordance with Table 2.
Subsection (1) does not apply in any of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharge quality does not exceed a maximum BOD5 and TSS of 10 mg/L each;
the discharge does not exceed a maximum daily flow of 50 m3/d;
the discharge is diluted such that, at the outside boundary of the initial dilution zone, the dilution ratio exceeds 100:1;
a director waives the requirement on the basis that the discharge does not adversely affect the receiving environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water must conduct toxicity testing if an environmental impact study indicates that testing is necessary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must determine toxicity in accordance with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Environment Canada's Biological Test Method: Reference Method for Determining Acute Lethality of Effluents to Rainbow Trout (Reference Method EPS 1/RM/13), and
if applicable, Environment Canada's Procedure for pH Stabilization During the Testing of Acute Lethality of Wastewater Effluent to Rainbow Trout (Reference Method EPS 1/RM/50).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Discharge is not toxic if it passes a 96-hour bioassay test with a mortality rate of no more than 50%, as defined by the method referred to in subsection (1) (a).
If a discharge fails a routine toxicity test under section 58 [toxicity monitoring requirements], the discharger must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify a director immediately, and
conduct a confirmation toxicity test within 14 days of the date the previous toxicity sample was taken.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When conducting a confirmation toxicity test or when monitoring after a confirmed failure of a toxicity test, a discharger must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: monitor ammonia levels at the same time, and
record the temperature and pH of the sample at the time of sampling.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a discharge fails 2 consecutive toxicity tests, the discharger must conduct monitoring at the frequency specified in Column 3 of Table 2 in section 58 until the discharge passes 3 consecutive toxicity tests, after which time testing reverts to the frequency specified in Column 2 of that table.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must pay the following to a director:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on giving notice under section 16 (1) [changes to registration], an application fee in accordance with section 2 of the Permit and Approval Fees and Charges Regulation;

on each anniversary of the date on which registration is effective under section 10 (2) [registration], an annual charge in accordance with section 3 of the Permit and Approval Fees and Charges Regulation, based on the quality and quantity of the discharge as indicated under section 12 (b) [technical information] of this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Records respecting septic tank pump outs
bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger using a septic tank must provide pump out records to a director in the frequency set out in the operating plan prepared under section 23 [general requirements of operating plans].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information and records to be retained
bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must retain for inspection by an officer at any time a copy of, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information and records submitted on registration under Division 2 [Registration] of Part 2,
a record prepared under section 42 (2) [overflows],
all outfall inspection reports,
municipal effluent flow and municipal effluent quality monitoring data, and
receiving environment monitoring data.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a discharger is no longer covered under an assurance plan acceptable to a director, the discharger must notify a director in writing within 30 days of the date coverage ends.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger who is covered by an assurance plan accepted under Division 5 [Security and Assurance Plans] of Part 2 must, on or before March 31 of each year, provide to a director an annual report detailing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: what quality assurance and technical, financial and management resources are in place under the assurance plan, and
how effective the quality assurance and technical, financial and management resources have been during the previous calendar year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving a report, a director may give notice requiring the discharger to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the assurance plan, or
submit a new assurance plan for review and acceptance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reports respecting discharge to ground and water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For discharges for which the contributory population is less than 10 000 persons, a discharger, on receiving notice from a director, must prepare and submit a report

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on or before a date specified by the director,
in a form acceptable to, and containing any information requested by, the director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For discharges for which the contributory population is 10 000 persons or more, a discharger must submit an annual report that includes all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a compendium of the municipal effluent flow, municipal effluent quality and receiving environment monitoring data and associated quality control work submitted under sections 86 [monitoring requirements for discharges to ground] and 87 [additional monitoring requirements];
any effect of the discharge on the quality of the receiving environment, using appropriate statistical and graphical analysis;
any trends in environmental quality in receiving environments affected by the discharge, using background or pre-discharge data and all the years of record in which the discharge has taken place;
if source control, water conservation and education programs related to municipal wastewater quality or quantity, or both, have been implemented, an update of the previous year's achievements;
an update of the problems identified in the previous year and the corrective actions taken;
any planned improvements of wastewater facilities for the coming year;
if reduce, reuse and recycle initiatives related to municipal wastewater quality or quantity, or both, have been implemented, an update of the previous year's achievements;
documentation of historic and projected contributory population and remaining plant capacity;
if applicable, the status of any capital replacement fund established by the discharger;
an outline of the projected monitoring dates for the next year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An annual report under subsection (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be prepared, and the analysis done, by a suitably qualified professional,
provide an interpretation of monitoring data,
be in a form acceptable to, and contain any information requested by, a director, and
be submitted to a director before May 1 of each year.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On receiving notice from a director, a discharger must make an annual report under subsection (2) available to an individual requesting it, or to the public, by posting it on the Internet or providing a copy to the local public library, or both.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water must submit to a director and a health officer an annual report containing all of the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the quality and quantity of reclaimed water;
the method of use and any diversion to an alternate disposal method or to storage;
user information, and communication materials related to the use of reclaimed water;
the results of any receiving environment monitoring required under this regulation;
the projected monitoring dates for the next year;
the reason for any non-compliance with this regulation and the corrective action taken.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Specific Requirements for Discharge To Ground

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies only in respect of discharging to ground.
In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: aquifer includes any soil or rock formation that has sufficient porosity and water yielding ability to permit the extraction or injection of water at rates of 5 L/minute or more;
disposal site perimeter means the outer edge of the subsurface treatment works;
groundwater mounding effect means the vertical rise in the water table that occurs in response to a discharge.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Part, municipal effluent is classed as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: class A, being high quality municipal effluent resulting from advanced treatment with the addition of disinfection and nitrogen reduction;
class B, being high quality municipal effluent resulting from advanced treatment;
class C, being municipal effluent resulting from secondary treatment;
class D, being municipal effluent resulting from treatment in a septic tank.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, zone of influence means the zone around a water well that, in the opinion of a qualified professional, supplies water to the well.
A person must not discharge, within the zone of influence, municipal effluent to ground unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the requirements set out in this Part are met, and
the discharged effluent is disinfected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must ensure that a discharge of municipal effluent within 300 m of a drinking water source meets class A municipal effluent requirements.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person discharges municipal effluent to ground,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the initial dilution zone is the 3-dimensional subsurface zone where mixing of the municipal effluent and groundwater occurs, and
the boundary of the initial dilution zone is the vertical extension into the ground of the property boundaries of the land into which discharging occurs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, subsurface travel time means the actual time, including the time spent in the unsaturated and saturated zones, required for municipal effluent to travel from the disposal site perimeter to the point where the municipal effluent

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: surfaces,
reaches a property line, or
is intercepted by a water well.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that the subsurface travel time is at least,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for class A or B municipal effluent, 6 days, or
for class C or D municipal effluent, 10 days.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that discharge does not surface, or cause the groundwater table to be raised to the surface, as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 m beyond the disposal site perimeter;
more than 30 m beyond the disposal site perimeter, unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the discharge does not cause water quality parameters to fail to meet water quality guidelines, and
there will be no adverse impacts from the surfaced municipal effluent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must determine the calculated or actual maximum daily flow.
A qualified professional may use the actual maximum daily flow to design the wastewater facility if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the actual daily flow is equal to or greater than 37 m3/d,
water conservation measures are used, and
a restrictive covenant is placed on each property requiring that water conservation measures are continuously used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If actual maximum daily flow is used under subsection (2), daily discharge volume monitoring is required.
A discharger of class A, B or C municipal effluent must meet the applicable municipal effluent quality requirements set out in this section and listed in Table 3.
The median coliform values for 7 consecutive daily tests and any single value test must be less than the value specified in Table 3.
Despite subsection (1), for class C lagoon systems, the maximum TSS level must not exceed 60 mg/L.
In respect of class A and B municipal effluent that is discharged to a drainfield,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filtration is required to prevent solids carrying over into the disposal field, and
monitoring controls must be maintained to signal an alarm when filtration begins to malfunction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, unsaturated soil means the soil between the land surface and the water table where the soil pore spaces contain water at less than atmospheric pressure, as well as air and other gases.
The minimum unsaturated soil depth must be measured from the infiltrative surface to the highest water table, including the groundwater mounding effect or restrictive layer.
For chamber distribution systems, the bottom of the sidewall, or "foot" of the chamber, is considered to be the infiltrative surface.
For class A or B municipal effluent, a discharger must ensure that the minimum unsaturated soil depth is 0.5 m.
For class C or D municipal effluent, a discharger must ensure that the minimum unsaturated soil depth for maximum daily flows of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: less than 37 m3/d is 0.75 m, and
37 m3/d or more is 1 m.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must not discharge, above the following aquifer areas, municipal effluent having a total nitrogen content of more than 10 mg/L:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Abbotsford-Sumas Aquifer in Abbotsford;
the Hopington and Langley/Brookswood Aquifers in Langley;
the Lower Nechako River Aquifer in Prince George;
the Lower Cowichan River Aquifer in Duncan;
the Grand Forks Aquifer in Grand Forks;
the Merritt Aquifer in Merritt;
the Osoyoos West and Osoyoos East Aquifers in Osoyoos;
the Vedder River Fan Aquifer in Chilliwack;
the aquifers stretching from Osoyoos Lake to Tuc-el-Nuit Lake and from Tuc-el-Nuit Lake to Vaseux Lake.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that drainage pipes are at least the length set out for the applicable municipal effluent class and percolation rate, as listed in Table 4.
Despite subsection (1), a discharger may use a chamber distribution system with an equivalent length to the minimum pipe length listed in Table 4.
If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: percolation rates are less than 2 minutes per 25 mm,
the maximum daily flow is less than 37 m3/d, and
class A or B municipal effluent is discharged by pressure distribution,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: a discharger may use American Society for Testing and Materials C33 sand-filled trenches to reduce percolation.
If percolation rates exceed 20 minutes per 25 mm, a qualified professional must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: supervise construction, and

ensure that construction has not reduced the trench wall permeability, except that, for maximum daily flows of less than 37 m3/d, permeability may be reduced if the native undisturbed permeable soil depth exceeds 1.35 m as measured from the bottom of the field to the level of the water table.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 78 (1) [drainage pipe length requirements], a qualified professional may provide for a reduction in drainage pipe length to a maximum of 40% if both of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under section 74 (2) [calculating flow], a qualified professional uses the actual maximum daily flow to design the wastewater facility;
the drainfield discharges class A or B effluent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances set out in subsection (3), a qualified professional may design a drainfield with deeper, narrower trenches and reduce the drainage pipe length to a value equal to the product of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pipe length required under section 78, and
a factor of 1/H0.5 or 0.8, whichever is greater, where H is the drainage trench depth below pipe invert in metres.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The circumstances for the purposes of subsection (2) are as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: percolation rates are less than 5 minutes per 25 mm;
the maximum daily flow is equal to or greater than 37 m3/d;
the depth to groundwater, including any groundwater mounding effect, is more than 1 m below the bottom of the drainage trench.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pressure distribution system is used for drainage pipes fed by a dosing syphon or pump;
unless a pressure distribution system is used, the drainage pipe is at least 70 mm in diameter;
the drainage pipe cover is at least 0.15 m and meets local frost protection requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that visual inspection ports are installed in the drain field.
A discharger must ensure that all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drainage pipes are provided in 2 drain fields, each having at least the length of drainage pipe required under section 78 [drainage pipe length requirements] unless a reduction is permitted under section 79 [reductions in drainage pipe length];
a third undeveloped drain field is retained as a standby area;
drain fields are constructed with trenches spaced

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: such that there is at least 3 m between the centre of each trench, or
if the performance of the drain field would not be adversely affected, at least 2 m apart from each other with at least double the standby area;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: trenches are at least 0.6 m in width, with trench bottoms at least 0.3 m below the pipe invert.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For all discharges to ground and standby areas, a discharger must ensure that setbacks from the area into which discharging occurs are at least the distance set out in Table 5.
A discharger must ensure that subsurface fields, the standby area and a surrounding buffer strip as set out in row 2 ("building drain, buffer strip") of Table 5

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are kept free of buildings or hard surfacing of any kind, and
are not used for building drains or any activity that may cause damage to the system or interfere with its operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The wastewater facility itself is a building for the purposes of row 2 of Table 5.
For the purposes of row 6 of Table 5, if, based on a hydrogeological assessment to determine the minimum distance required to protect the water quality of a water well,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the distance from the water well must be extended in accordance with the hydrogeological assessment, or
the maximum daily flow is more than or equal to 37 m3/d,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the distance from the water well may be decreased, if authorized by a director, to a distance of no less than 90 m.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Infiltration Basins, Sand Mounds and Seepage Beds

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that infiltration basins meet the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 2 basins must be provided to allow cleaning of one basin while the other is operating and to act as a safety factor for unusual conditions;
for 2 basin systems, each basin must be capable of accepting all the municipal effluent under annual average rainfall conditions;
subject to Division 1 [General Requirements], discharge of municipal effluent to an infiltration basin meets at least class C requirements.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger may use sand mounds and seepage beds only if both of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sand mounds and seepage beds are constructed using American Society for Testing and Materials C33 sand to reduce percolation;
the discharger is authorized by a director to use the sand mounds and seepage beds.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a discharger must install monitoring wells in sufficient number and orientation, as determined by a qualified professional, to measure background and receiving environment water quality.
For the purpose of subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the qualified professional must consider horizontal as well as vertical arrays for sampling, and
at least 4 wells per aquifer are required, one of which must be a background monitoring well.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Monitoring requirements for discharges to ground
bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must monitor municipal effluent quality and quantity in accordance with section 87 [additional monitoring requirements] and Table 6, 7 or 8, as applicable, of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of a discharge having a maximum daily flow of 500 m3/d or more, after 60 days of compliance with the quality limit,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharger must conduct weekly presence or absence testing for coliform monitoring,
if the presence of any coliform is detected, daily fecal coliform testing must be reinstated until the quality limit is in compliance, and
for the purpose of paragraph (b), 7 tests must be conducted to demonstrate compliance before weekly presence or absence testing may be resumed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger of class D municipal effluent must monitor 24-hour flow as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the maximum daily flow is less than 50 m3/d, weekly;
if the maximum daily flow is 50 m3/d or more but less than 500 m3d, twice each week, and
if the maximum daily flow is 500 m3/d or more, daily.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must submit gathered data under this section to a director, if the maximum daily flow is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: less than 50 m3/d, twice each year, or
50 m3/d or more, quarterly.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger of class A or B municipal effluent must install a continuous monitoring system.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Specific Requirements for Discharge To Water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Part applies only in respect of discharging to water.
In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: diffuser means a section of pipe that diffuses municipal effluent into water through a series of ports;

estuary means that portion of a receiving water lying below the farthest point upstream of detectable changes in water movement or chemistry through mixing of fresh and salt water and due to tidal action;
mean low water means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for marine waters, the datum provided on the most recently published marine chart published by the Canadian Hydrographic Service for the location,
for lakes, the point of contact between the lake surface and the shore at the time when the surface is at its average annual minimum elevation based on the last 10 years of records, and
for streams and rivers, the point of contact between the stream or river surface and the shore during the 2-year return period 7-day flow.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not discharge municipal effluent to water unless the requirements set out in this Part are met.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initial dilution zone for water generally

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person discharges municipal effluent to water, the initial dilution zone is the 3-dimensional zone around the point of discharge where mixing of the municipal effluent and the receiving water occurs.
The edge of the initial dilution zone must be located at least 300 m away from the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: recreational areas;
aboriginal, commercial or recreational shellfish harvesting areas;
domestic or agricultural water intakes;
any sensitive area requiring protection identified in a notice given by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Initial dilution zones may overlap only if the combined effects do not cause water quality parameters, outside the combined initial dilution zone, to fail to meet water quality guidelines.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initial dilution zone for marine waters and lakes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of calculating the initial dilution zone for marine waters or a lake, both of the following, measured from the point of discharge and from mean low water, apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the height is the distance from the bed to the water surface;
the radius is the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 100 m, and
25% of the width of the body of water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For discharge from an outfall diffuser, the radius referred to in subsection (1) (b) (i) must be measured from the first and last diffuser ports.
In embayed marine waters and lakes, the initial dilution zone must not extend closer to shore than mean low water.
In open marine waters, the edge of the initial dilution zone must be located outside of the shallow water zone in which surf will form along the shore.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Initial dilution zone for streams, rivers and estuaries

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of calculating the initial dilution zone for a stream, river or estuary, all of the following, measured from the point of discharge and from mean low water, apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the height is the distance from the bed to the water surface;
the width, perpendicular to the path of the stream, is the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 100 m, and
25% of the width of the stream or estuary;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the length, parallel to the path of the stream, is the distance between a point 100 m upstream and a point that is the lesser of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 100 m downstream, and
a distance downstream at which the width of the municipal effluent plume equals the width determined under paragraph (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For estuaries,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the stream flow is the fresh water content, and
the initial dilution zone must not extend closer to shore than mean low water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must meet the applicable municipal effluent quality requirements as set out in this section and as listed in Table 9, 10 or 11.

Subject to subsection (5), if the dilution ratio in respect of discharges to streams, rivers and estuaries is less than 100:1, a qualified professional conducting an environmental impact study must determine if municipal effluent quality must be better than that shown in Table 9, 10 or 11, as applicable.

Subject to subsection (5), if the dilution ratio in respect of discharges to streams, rivers and estuaries used for recreational or domestic water extraction is less than 40:1, a person must not discharge unless all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the discharge meets advanced treatment requirements;
no other discharge options are available;
the discharge is authorized by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), in respect of seasonal discharges or discharges to streams, rivers and estuaries that are not used for recreational or domestic water extraction, a director may approve the use of secondary treatment if there is a minimum dilution ratio of 20:1.
Discharge is prohibited if the dilution ratio is less than 10:1.
For discharges to marine waters having a maximum daily flow of less than 10 m3/d, a discharger must use a septic tank that meets the design requirements set out in section 39 [septic tanks].
For all lagoon systems, the maximum TSS level is 60 mg/L.
