bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies only if the maximum daily flow is more than or equal to 50 m3/day.
For flows up to and equaling 2 times the ADWF, treatment and municipal effluent quality requirements are determined by daily flow multiples that require secondary treatment.
If flows are more than 2 times the ADWF during a storm or equivalent snowmelt event with a less than 5-year return period, a discharger must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a liquid waste management plan or specific study, and
implement the plan's or study's measures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3), a director may give notice that the factor is increased to a maximum of 3 times the ADWF for areas of the province where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: permafrost or freezing ground conditions require roof drains to be connected to the municipal wastewater collection system, and
connections must be made in accordance with a practice acceptable to a local building inspector or an equivalent practice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may substitute, in accordance with section 8 [director may substitute requirements], different requirements for the total phosphorus and orthophosphate requirements specified in Table 11, as set out in section 94 [municipal effluent quality requirements], if an environmental impact study demonstrates that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: receiving waters would not be subject to an undesirable degree of increased biological activity because of the phosphorus addition,
lower municipal effluent concentrations than those shown in Table 11 in section 94 are necessary, or
a mass load criteria may be needed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must determine the maximum allowable municipal effluent ammonia concentration at the "end of pipe" by a back calculation, from the edge of the initial dilution zone, that considers

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ambient temperature and pH characteristics of the receiving water, and
water quality guidelines for chronic ammonia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger, unless using a septic tank, must ensure that the number of fecal coliform organisms meets the following requirements, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if discharging to shellfish bearing waters at the edge of the initial dilution zone, the median or geometric mean MPN of fecal coliform organisms must be less than 14/100 mL, with not more than 10% of the samples exceeding 43/100 mL;
if discharging to recreational use waters, the geometric mean number of fecal coliform organisms at the edge of the initial dilution zone must be less than or equal to 200/100 mL.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The geometric mean, as determined from the bacteriological results of the last 5 samples for which analyses have been completed over the last 30 days, must not be more than the coliform limits specified in subsection (1) (a) or (b), as applicable.
The median coliform values for 7 consecutive daily tests and any single value test must be less than the values specified in this section.

Unless a director gives notice of a maximum seasonal loading rate in respect of the body of water, a discharger must not discharge to the following bodies of water municipal effluent having a total annual average phosphorus content of more than 0.25 mg/L:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the Okanagan Basin;
the Christina Lake Basin;
the Thompson River at Kamloops;
the Cowichan River;
the Nicola River at Merritt;
the Cheakamus River at Whistler.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The annual average phosphorus content must be calculated based on a sampling method and frequency acceptable to a director.

A person other than a municipality must not discharge into the Okanagan Basin, and a municipality that discharges into the Okanagan Basin must not discharge effluent that has a total nitrogen content of 6 mg/L or more.
The terms of reference of an enhanced environmental impact study under this section must be established in consultation with a director.

Discharge to the Saanich Inlet is under a moratorium, and a discharger must not discharge to the Saanich Inlet unless the discharger first conducts an enhanced environmental impact study as recommended by the Saanich Inlet Study.

A discharger must not discharge municipal effluent to any of the following areas unless the discharger first conducts an enhanced environmental impact study and a director gives notice that advanced treatment will protect the receiving environment:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lakes having a surface area of less than 100 ha;
waters within

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Southern Interior Region,
the Interior Douglas Fir Biogeoclimatic Zone,
the Ponderosa Pine Biogeoclimatic Zone,
the Montane Spruce Biogeoclimatic Zone, or
the Bunchgrass Biogeoclimatic Zone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must design an outfall such that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: initial dilution zone requirements under this regulation are met,
air entrapment is prevented,
adequate weighting is provided to prevent movement from currents, ice or possible entrainment of air, and
the outfall is protected from corrosion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must ensure that outfall diffusers are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: located at a sufficient depth to maximize the frequency that municipal effluent is trapped below the surface of the water,
located to intercept the predominant current and avoid small currents that tend to move toward the shore,
designed to ensure that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: each diffuser section will provide at least 10:1 dilution within the initial dilution zone, and
outside the initial dilution zone, discharge does not cause water quality parameters to fail to meet water quality guidelines, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designed to achieve maximum dilution in a river, stream or estuary located in the channel in which most of the water flows.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must ensure that outfalls are located

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: such that they are protected from wave, boat and marine activity, and
at a depth of at least

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 40 m below mean low water in the Okanagan Basin, and
subject to subparagraph (i), 10 m below mean low water in estuaries, lakes or marine waters with a surface area greater than 100 ha.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional outfall requirements for estuaries, lakes and marine waters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: D1 means the depth (m) of the shallowest diffuser port below mean low water;
D2 means the distance (m) to the closest port of the diffuser from mean low water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A qualified professional must ensure that outfalls to estuaries, lakes or marine waters with a surface area greater than 100 ha meet the following depth, flow and distance requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: D1 must be at least 10 m and D2 must be at least 30 m;

subject to paragraph (a), for discharges of less than 5 000 m3/d, the calculated critical flow must be greater than or equal to the maximum daily flow (m3/d), with the calculated critical flow being the greater positive value of
subject to paragraph (a), for discharges equal to or more than 5 000 m3/d, D1 and D2 must be determined by an environmental impact study and computer modelling of the discharge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of subsection (2) (b), if an outfall has a diffuser, the terminus of the outfall is the closest and shallowest port.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A discharger must ensure that all outfalls are marked on shore with a sign that meets the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the sign must indicate, with wording acceptable to a director, the length and depth of the outfall;
the sign must be at least 1 m2;

the colours of the lettering and the background of the sign must contrast sufficiently with each other, and the sign must be located, such that the wording is clearly visible from both land and water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To ensure the outfall is operating as designed, a discharger must have each outfall associated with a discharge inspected by a qualified person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: once every 5 years, or
at a frequency specified in a notice given by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An inspection must include examination of the entire length of the pipe and diffuser for leaks, breaks and blockages.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Monitoring requirements for discharges to water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A discharger must monitor the applicable municipal effluent quality and quantity in accordance with this section and Table 12.
In respect of discharging to open marine waters that have a maximum daily flow of less than 10 m3/d, monitoring of BOD5, TSS and fecal coliforms is not required.
A discharger must submit to a director data gathered under this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of discharges having a maximum daily flow range of less than 50 000 m3/d, twice each year, and
in respect of discharges having a maximum daily flow range of 50 000 m3/d or more, quarterly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Part, uses of reclaimed water are categorized as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indirect potable reuse, being any use of reclaimed water to replenish a potential potable water source;
greater exposure potential, being uses for which public contact is likely or that present a risk to the receiving environment;
moderate exposure potential, being uses

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for which public contact is likely minimal,
for which public access to the reclaimed water is restricted and users are educated as to the risks posed by the use of the reclaimed water, or
that present a moderate risk to the receiving environment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lower exposure potential, being uses

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for which public access to the reclaimed water is restricted and users are not likely to have contact with the reclaimed water,
that are commercial or industrial in nature and users are educated as to the risks posed by the use of the reclaimed water, or
that present a low risk to the receiving environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Categories of reclaimed water are determined based on the point of distribution or use.
Subject to subsection (3), a person must not provide reclaimed water unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: gives written notice to a health officer, at least 60 days before registering under Division 2 [Registration] of Part 2, of the proposed use of the reclaimed water, and
receives authorization under subsection (2) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 60 days of receiving notice under subsection (1), a health officer may, in writing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibit the person from providing reclaimed water for the proposed use, or
authorize the person to provide reclaimed water for the proposed use, subject to the conditions specified by the health officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may provide reclaimed water without the notice or authorization referred to in subsection (1) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use of the reclaimed water is specifically authorized under a local service area bylaw, and
under the bylaw, the municipality or a person under contract to the municipality is responsible for ensuring

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: compliance with this regulation, and
that proper operation and maintenance will occur.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Indirect potable reuse of reclaimed water
bcl:section.bcl:text: If reclaimed water is to be used for indirect potable reuse, a provider of reclaimed water must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conduct an enhanced environmental impact study, having terms of reference established in consultation with a director,
consult with all persons and organizations who may have an interest or duty that may be impacted by the use of the reclaimed water, and
be authorized by a director to use the reclaimed water for indirect potable reuse.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless a director provides otherwise under section 8 [director may substitute requirements], initial dilution zones are not applicable to reclaimed water used for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stream augmentation,
creating impoundments, or
maintaining wetlands or marshes.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Municipal effluent quality requirements for reclaimed water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water must meet the applicable municipal effluent quality requirements set out in this section and listed in Table 13.
Turbidity limits under Table 13 must be met before disinfection of the reclaimed water.
For the purposes of fecal coliform monitoring requirements under Table 13,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the median value, as determined from the bacteriological results of the last 5 samples for which analyses have been completed, must not be more than the coliform limits specified in Table 13, and
if irrigating food crops that will be eaten raw, Escherichia coli must be monitored daily and be less than 1 CFU/100 mL or 2 MPN/100 mL.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Table 13 Municipal Effluent Quality Requirements For Reclaimed Water

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to municipal effluent quality requirements if the use of reclaimed water is categorized as having greater, moderate or lower exposure potential.

A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that reclaimed water is not used for irrigation, or is not impounded, within 30 m of any water well or in-ground reservoir used for domestic supply unless a director authorizes a lesser distance on the basis that special circumstances exist.
A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that the reclaimed water is not used for irrigation within the 3 days before, and during, the harvesting of crops.
A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that windblown spray will not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: go beyond the boundaries of the property to which the reclaimed water is applied, or
reach areas accessible to the public.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that the maximum ground surface slope when applying the reclaimed water is not more than 20%.
A provider of reclaimed water must develop information and communication materials related to the use of the reclaimed water, and provide copies annually to all users.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements if greater exposure potential

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to municipal effluent quality requirements only if the use of reclaimed water is categorized as having greater exposure potential.
To remove viruses, a provider of reclaimed water must do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide for the chemical addition of a coagulant or polymer, followed by filtration;
provide for 60-day storage after secondary treatment, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: municipal effluent quality requirements are met after storage and treatment,
no short circuiting is occurring or likely to occur, and
no viruses at levels of concern to a health officer are detected in the reclaimed water;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide an equivalent form of treatment that is authorized by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of fecal coliform monitoring,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: based on an initial 60 days of compliance with the daily fecal coliform quality limit, a provider of reclaimed water may conduct weekly fecal coliform testing, and
if the presence of fecal coliform is detected, daily testing must be reinstated and 7 consecutive non-detect results must be achieved before weekly testing may be resumed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If ground discharge is the alternate disposal method and 5 years have elapsed without issue, the constructed drainage pipe length as specified in section 78 [drainage pipe length requirements] may be reduced if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: recommended by a suitably qualified professional, and
a director authorizes the reduction.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements if moderate exposure potential

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to municipal effluent quality requirements only if the use of reclaimed water is categorized as having moderate exposure potential.

A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that, if the reclaimed water is used to irrigate commercially processed food crops, the crops undergo chemical or physical processing sufficient to destroy pathogens, including canning, heat treatment, fermentation or pickling, before sale to the public or others.
A provider of reclaimed water must ensure that, if the reclaimed water is used to irrigate livestock grazing fields,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: milking animals are prohibited from grazing for 6 days after irrigation ends, and
other livestock are prohibited from grazing for 3 days after irrigation ends, unless the meat is inspected under the Meat Inspection Act (Canada).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Additional requirement if moderate or
low exposure potential
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the use of reclaimed water is categorized as having moderate or low exposure potential, a provider of reclaimed water must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensure that worker contact with the reclaimed water is minimized, and

provide, if frequent worker contact with the reclaimed water is likely, a higher level of disinfection to a maximum fecal coliform CFU of less than 14/100 mL, or equivalent MPN, based on daily sampling.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water must not provide the reclaimed water for use unless it is first disinfected.

Despite section 52 (2) [disinfection and chlorination], a provider of reclaimed water must ensure that, when distributing reclaimed water, the minimal total chlorine residual at the point of use is maintained at 0.5 mg/L unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the addition of chlorine will detrimentally impact aquatic flora or fauna, or

at the point of use, fecal coliforms remain below the levels set in Table 13 in section 108 [municipal effluent quality requirements for reclaimed water], and users are adequately informed regarding appropriate use of the reclaimed water.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Alternate Disposal or Storage, and Distribution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not provide or use reclaimed water unless all of the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is an alternate method of disposing of the reclaimed water that meets the requirements of this regulation or is authorized by a director;

treatment processes are built with the minimum number of components specified in the applicable reliability category for the alternate method of disposal, as described in section 35 [general component and reliability requirements];

if there is no immediate means of conveyance of the municipal effluent or reclaimed water to the alternate disposal method, the wastewater facility has 48 hours' emergency storage outside the treatment system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1) (a), a director may waive the requirement for an alternate method of disposal for reclaimed water that is not generated from residential development or institutional settings if an alternate method is not required to protect public health or the receiving environment and the wastewater facility has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 48 hours' emergency storage outside the treatment system and the ability to shut down generation of municipal wastewater within 24 hours, or
a dedicated storage system that is designed to accommodate

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at least 20 days of design average daily municipal effluent flow at any time,
the maximum anticipated volume of surplus reclaimed water, and
storm or snowmelt events with a less than 5-year return period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsections (1) (a) and (2), if reclaimed water is discharged from a wastewater facility directly into a wetland, a director may waive the requirement for an alternate method of disposal if an alternate method of disposal is not required to protect public health or the receiving environment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Failure to meet municipal effluent quality requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If municipal effluent does not meet municipal effluent quality requirements, a provider of reclaimed water must ensure that the municipal effluent is diverted immediately to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an alternate method of disposal, as provided for in section 114 (1) (a) [alternate disposal or storage], or
emergency storage or a dedicated storage system, as described in section 114 (1) (c) or (2),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: until municipal effluent quality requirements are met and reclaimed water uses may continue.
A provider of reclaimed water must identify in the operating plan under section 23 [general requirements of operating plans]

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the diversion procedures under subsection (1), and
the conditions under which the reclaimed water is redirected back to the reclaimed water use.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If emergency storage as described under section 114 [alternate disposal or storage], is used, a provider of reclaimed water must ensure that the wastewater facility

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately begins conveyance of municipal effluent or the reclaimed water to an alternate disposal method before emergency storage capacity is reached, or
stops generating municipal wastewater within 24 hours.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, dual distribution system means a water distribution system that distributes both potable and non-potable water to the same service area.

A provider of reclaimed water must not use a dual distribution system to convey reclaimed water unless the system has design, construction, maintenance and inspection safeguards to prevent cross connections.

A person must not operate or maintain a reclaimed water distribution system unless the person is certified in cross connection control inspections, conducted for the purposes of controlling and protecting potable water systems against contamination from unprotected cross connections.
A provider of reclaimed water must monitor the applicable discharge quality and quantity in accordance with this section and Table 14.
A provider of reclaimed water must monitor groundwater levels and water flows to ensure that reclaimed water use, or an alternate method of discharge, is managed to avoid adverse effects.
A provider of reclaimed water must submit reports as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for reclaimed water categorized as having indirect potable use, weekly;
for reclaimed water categorized as having greater exposure potential, monthly;
for reclaimed water categorized as having moderate or lower exposure potential, quarterly.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (3), a director may authorize reports to be submitted less often than is required under that subsection.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Table 14 Monitoring Requirements For Reclaimed Water

bcl:section.bcl:text: A provider of reclaimed water categorized as having indirect potable use or greater exposure potential must install a continuous monitoring system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of sections 23, 32, 33, 40, 45 (a), (b) or (c), 47, 48, 50 (1) or (2), 53, 63, 67 (c), 105 (1) or 117 (2) or (3) commits an offence.
A person commits an offence if the person, with intent to mislead,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submits false monitoring data,
fails to retain monitoring data under section 63 (d) or (e) [information and records to be retained],
makes a false report, or
fails to submit a report under section 66 (1) [reports respecting discharge to ground and water], or a report containing the information required under section 66 (2) (a) or (3) (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who commits an offence as described in subsection (1) or (2) is liable to a penalty not exceeding $200 000.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition registrations under the Municipal Sewage Regulation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person registered under the Municipal Sewage Regulation, B.C. Reg. 129/99, immediately before its repeal, is deemed to be registered under this regulation.
A person deemed to be registered under subsection (1) of this section must, subject to the exercise of the director's discretion under the Act and this regulation,
